{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3680635,"name":"Murilo Miranda Santos","username":"murilo404","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/49beb7/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-07-13T14:07:12.288Z","cooked":"

Good morning everyone! I’m an FRC programmer on a relatively new team. We’re currently using the offseason to improve our programming style and practices. From there, we came up with the idea of putting our swerve in closed-loop with PID control. But before we do, I’d like to ask some more experienced programmers for their opinions:

1: What were the results?
2: In your opinion, is it worth putting it in closed-loop?
3: What were the challenges during the process of switching to closed-loop?
4: Were there any downsides to closed-loop?

If anyone can answer my questions, I’d appreciate it. The link to my code is below for anyone who’s curious or needs to analyze it.

github.com

GitHub - muriloMiranda404/c-digo-para-atualiza-o-

Contribute to muriloMiranda404/c-digo-para-atualiza-o- development by creating an account on GitHub.

My team is switching to it next season, and from what we’ve heard from other teams, there are virtually no downsides. It takes some processing off of the Rio, prevents unintended behavior if your code has loop overruns, and in some cases can give you better and more responsive control over your mechanisms.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-07-13T14:28:27.497Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":234,"readers_count":233,"score":111.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":504206,"topic_slug":"closed-swerve","display_username":"Ethan Grieshop","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62698,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4611 Programmer + Driver"},"post_url":"/t/closed-swerve/504206/2","custom_user_title":"4611 Programmer + Driver","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3680657,"name":"Nolan Barker","username":"therekrab","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/therekrab/{size}/248500_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-13T15:29:57.705Z","cooked":"

We’ve been using closed-loop control over velocity for a while now (2+ seasons for sure), and I can say that this is definitely true. It takes a little bit of time to tune the PID controller and feedforward, but this comes with a great benefit. For example, we have setup friction compensation as part of our feedforward constants, which is great for small, precise movemements. The drivers probably don’t notice this as much, but when talking about alignment where small changes in position can be the difference between a miss and a score, this was well noticed. That level of accuracy in velocity control is very helpful.

It’s also nice for motion tracking if you can just tell the robot how fast it needs to be going, and let the motors themselves handle how to get there.

I’m unsure what you mean by “closed loop”. Most teams I know of use on-board motor PiD for steering. It’s not worth using something like motion magic since you can pretty much treat the steering as an over-damped mechanism that has little accel / decel.

Some teams use velocity control for the wheel velocity. I’d recommend also on-board if you’re using krakens or falcons. I’m not sure about the rev software / hardware stack: you would have to ask other users since their velocity control and low count encoders have been an issue in the past.

Could you clarify? Are you just asking about moving things to on-board the motors themselves? Because you can use PiD control onboard the Rio without issue, but the motors will be better.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-07-13T17:24:43.347Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":125,"readers_count":124,"score":25.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":504206,"topic_slug":"closed-swerve","display_username":"Tom Line","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 1498"},"post_url":"/t/closed-swerve/504206/4","custom_user_title":"Team 1498","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3680761,"name":"paulonis","username":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-07-13T18:57:14.407Z","cooked":"

As others have mentioned, closed-loop (feedback) control for the steering motor is required. I’m assuming you are asking about feedback control of the drive motor. You should be doing nearly all of the drive motor speed control with feedforward. If your kinematics are asking for 3.1 meters per second (for example) from a module drive motor, feedforward calculations should be providing the motor voltage required to deliver that speed. There should not be much speed error left after applying well-tuned feedforward, but there will always be some. That’s where the choice comes in to either apply feedback control (usually P only) to attempt to reduce the error or not. There isn’t a lot of downside to applying some feedback. If your proportional gain is way too low, it’s like feedback isn’t being used and so not much different than not even trying. If your proportional gain is way too high. you will get oscillations (cycles) in your module speeds and the base will be un-drivable. That’s the scenario you need to avoid. If your proportional gain is a bit too high, you will get some overshoots in response to changing speed requests, which you might or might not notice in driving. There is a pretty wide range of proportional gain from kind of low through optimal and then a little on the high side where closing the loop with speed feedback is helpful.

I echo the comment of being wary of speed control with NEO/SparkMax. The velocity filtering adds effective time delay in the feedback path which limits the amount of proportional gain that can be applied before causing instability. The problem is more severe in speed loops that respond very quickly, like a shooter with low rotating mass. For swerve drive, the mass of the robot limits how fast the wheel velocity can change such that the velocity filtering does not dominate the closed loop dynamics and reasonable speed control is usually possible. You can likely get away with NEOs on the drive side of the swerve modules, but I’d prefer Vortexes, Krakens, or Falcons in that application.

Two reasons you should consider closing the loop on swerve module drive speed are:

  1. Small errors in speed among modules, sometimes caused by slight differences in friction between the module drivetrains, can result in the robot rotating as it is commanded to drive straight. Closing the loop on module speeds can often reduce or eliminate this issue.
  2. You are likely to need good chassis speed control for autonomous path following, driving to a pose, driving to a target, or similar higher-level objectives. Performance is usually better if module speed control is very good so the higher-level controllers are not having to correct as much.
